chapter: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question:
Question 1: A patient presented with a deformity as shown in the image below. What is this deformity 
known as?
questions.explanation:
In the given image, the midline of the dorsum of the nose from the frontonasal angle to the tip is 
curved in a C- or S-shaped manner which is known as crooked nose deformity. Option B: Deviated nose - midline is straight but deviated to one side. 347 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: Hump nose is due to excess of bony or cartilaginous dorsum. Option D: Saddle nose is depressed nasal dorsum. 348 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: Question 2: In which of the following patients will you not expect a saddle nose deformity?

options.a: A VDRL positive patient with gumma of the nasal septum
options.b: A patient with lateral madarosis and leonine facies
options.c: A boxer who developed bilateral nasal obstruction after a trauma to the nose
options.d: A patient with growth hormone excess and a large nose.

questions.explanation:
Option D is a case of acromegaly, in which there may be enlargement of the nose. Saddle nose 
deformity only occurs when the bridge of the nose collapses. Causes for saddle nose/depressed dorsum of nose: • Nasal trauma causing depressed fractures - most common etiology. • Excessive removal of septum in submucous resection • Destruction of septal cartilage by haematoma or abscess • Leprosy • Syphilis • Tuberculosis. Option A is a case of tertiary syphilis. Option B is a case of lepromatous leprosy. Option C is a case of septal hematoma.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question:
Question 3: 339 
Sold by @itachibot A newborn developed respiratory distress immediately after delivery. The paediatrician was 
unable to pass the nasogastric tube through both the nares. Which of the following 
statements is false about the above diagnosis?

options.a: It is due to persistence of bucconasal membrane
options.b: Can be associated with CHARGE syndrome.
options.c: Bony obstruction is more common than membranous obstruction
options.d: Immediate tracheostomy to be done to maintain the airway.

questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of bilateral choanal atresia and immediate tracheostomy 
is not indicated. Simply securing a feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway and forces the 
infant to breathe through the mouth. This is known as McGovern’s technique and obviates the 
need for tracheostomy. 349 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question:
Question 4: What is the most common presentation of a patient with the pathology shown in the CT 
below?
questions.explanation:
Neonates with bilateral choanal atresia (image) present with respiratory distress at birth. 
Neonates are natural nose breathers, and do not breathe from their mouths.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: Question 5: Choanal atresia is not associated with which of the following defects?
questions.explanation:
Choanal atresia may be associated with CHARGE syndrome. Renal angiomyolipoma is not a part 
of CHARGE syndrome. • C- Coloboma of the eye • H- Heart defects • A- Atresia of the choana • R- Retarded growth and development • G- Genital anomalies • E- Ear anomalies and hearing loss. Renal angiomyolipoma - It is one of the major features of tuberous sclerosis complex.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question:
Question 6: A 2-year-old child was brought with a soft, compressible swelling at the root of the nose. 
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario of isolated solitary mass arising from the root of the nose should raise 
the index of suspicion of nasal meningocele or meningoencephalocele. It is the herniation of brain 
tissue along with its meninges through a congenital bony defect. 350 
Sold by @itachibot Nasal obstruction is the most common symptom. It presents as a cystic, bluish, compressible, 
translucent mass at the root of the nose (nasofrontal variety), side of the nose (nasoethmoid 
variety), or at the anteromedial aspect of the orbit (nasoorbital variety). Furstenberg's test: compression of the ipsilateral internal jugular vein usually causes an 
encephalocele to enlarge. Investigation: CT or MRI. Treatment: Transnasal endoscopic excision with the closure of the defect using bone or cartilage 
graft along with temporalis fascia and fat.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following statements about nasal glioma is false?
questions.explanation:
There is no CSF leakage in nasal glioma. It is a nipped-off portion of an encephalocele with no 
communication with the cranial cavity. They usually present as a firm, subcutaneous swelling causing nasal obstruction. Furstenberg's test - compression of the ipsilateral internal jugular vein usually causes an 
encephalocele to enlarge, but not a glioma. So, this test is negative in nasal glioma. 60% of nasal gliomas are extra-nasal, 30% are intranasal, and 10% are both intranasal and 
extra-nasal. CT scan reveals bony details while MRI reveals soft tissue details of a nasal glioma.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question:
Question 8: A surgeon suspects a rodent ulcer in a patient who presented with a finding as shown in the 
image. What is this condition also called? 341 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Basal cell carcinoma also known as rodent ulcer is the most common malignant tumour involving 
skin of nose. 351 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: Question 9: In a patient with findings as shown in the image, which of the following statements is false?

options.a: It is known as elephantiasis of the nose
options.b: It is seen in long standing cases of acne rosacea
options.c: It is commonly seen in middle aged women
options.d: It is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous glands

questions.explanation:
The given image is diagnostic of rhinophyma. It is commonly seen in men past middle age. Rhinophyma or potato tumour or elephantiasis of nose is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous glands. 
It is usually associated with long-standing cases of acne rosacea. Mostly seen at the tip of the nose 
and causes unsightly appearance and obstruction to breathing and vision. Treatment: Debulk of the tumor with carbon dioxide laser and the area is allowed to 
re-epithelialize. Sometimes the tumor is completely excised and skin is grafted over the raw area.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient presented with atrophic dry nasal mucosa, extensive crustations, and a woody hard 
external nose. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of rhinoscleroma. Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus). It has 3 stages: • Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis. • Granulomatous stage– Painless, non ulcerative Granulomatous nodules with subdermal 
infiltration giving feel of woody/hebra nose. • Cicatricial stage– Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. Deformity is called 
tapir nose. Option A: Atrophic rhinitis doesn’t cause woody nose. Option B: Rhinophyma or potato tumor is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland and presents as 
swelling over tip of nose. 352 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and 
presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question:
Question 11: A pathologist observed Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies on microscopy in a biopsy specimen 
taken from the nose. Which of the following is a false statement regarding the diagnosis?

options.b: Medical management include streptomycin and tetracycline.
options.c: Surgery is the treatment of choice for this disease

questions.explanation:
Biopsy findings of Mikulicz cells and Russell's bodies are characteristic findings in 
rhinoscleroma. Medical management is the mainstay treatment for rhinoscleroma. Streptomycin(1 
g/day) and tetracycline (2 g/day) are given for a minimum of 4-6 weeks and continued till 2 
consecutive biopsies are negative. Surgery is reserved to establish airway or correct deformity. Biopsy in the case of rhinoscleroma shows infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, 
lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells, and Russell bodies. Mikulicz cells are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing 
causative bacilli. Russell bodies are homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies found in the plasma cells. They 
occur due to the accumulation of immunoglobulins secreted by the plasma cells. The following image shows rhinoscleroma with Mikulicz cells. H&E showing a mixture of plasma cells (arrow), lymphocytes (short arrow), Miculikz cells 
which are vacuolated macrophages containing causative bacilli (double arrow). Option A: Rhinoscleroma is endemic in several parts of the world. In India, it is seen more often 
in the northern than in the southern parts. Option D: Organism can be cultured from biopsy material.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: Question 12: Snuffles are seen in which stage of syphilis?
questions.explanation:
Snuffles is seen in early congenital syphilis. 353 
Sold by @itachibot Nasal features in different stages of syphilis: Stage 
Feature Early congenital syphilis 
Snuffles Late congenital syphilis 
Gumma on the nasal septum Primary syphilis 
Primary chancre of the vestib 
ule of nose Secondary syphilis 
Simple rhinitis with crusting 
and fissuring in the nasal ves 
tibule Gumma on the nasal septum Tertiary form of acquired syp 
hilis
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question:
Question 13: An eighteen-year-old boy presented with a lesion over the nose as shown in the image. What 
is your diagnosis? 343 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shows apple jelly nodules seen in lupus vulgaris which is a low-grade tuberculous 
infection. These are brown, gelatinous nodules commonly affecting nasal vestibule or the skin of nose and 
face.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question:
Question 14: Given below is a histological section of a biopsy taken from a farmer who presented with a 
vascular polypoidal mass protruding from his left nostril. What is the causative organism for 
this condition?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario along with the histology (showing sporangia) is suggestive of 
rhinosporidiosis caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: Question 15: Rhinosporidium seeberi belongs to which group of organisms?
questions.explanation:
Rhinosporidium seeberi is an aquatic protista. Molecular biological techniques have demonstrated that this organism is an aquatic protistan 
parasite and it is currently included in a new class, the Mesomycetozoea, along with organisms 
causing similar infections in amphibians and fish.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question:
Question 16: A farmer presented with a mass protruding from his right nostril as shown in the figure 
below. On examination, mass bleeds easily on touch. Which of the statements is false 
regarding the diagnosis?

options.a: Water borne is the most common route of transmission
options.b: Endemic in southern states of India

questions.explanation:
Rhinosporidiosis affects immunocompetent individuals. 354 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question:
Question 17: A man who works in a cattle ranch presented with complaints of a mass protruding from the 
left nostril and blood-stained nasal discharge. The mass is pink, leafy, and polypoidal and is 
attached to the nasal septum. Biopsy from the lesion showed several sporangia. What is the 
treatment of choice for the above condition?
questions.explanation:
Surgical management (excision of the lesion with cauterisation of the base), is always the 
treatment of choice in rhinosporidiosis. No drug treatment has proved effective, although dapsone is tried in some cases. Followup of the 
patient after surgical management is necessary, as recurrence is common.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following statements is false about nasal T-cell lymphoma?
questions.explanation:
T-cell lymphoma is treated by radiation when it is localised and by chemotherapy when it is 
disseminated. The condition is also called as: • Non-healing midline granuloma • Midline granulomas reticulosis • Stewart’s granuloma • Nasal T-cell lymphoma • Lethal midline granuloma It is associated with EBV. Cells express T cell markers like CD56. Nasal obstruction and epistaxis are the presenting features. Destruction of mid-facial structures 
may be caused by the local invasion. Histologically, polymorphic lymphoid tissue with angiocentric and angioinvasive features are 
seen. 355 
Sold by @itachibot Rhinitis
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose
